qas.question: What are the most commonly used encodings of Unicode?

answers.text: UTF-8, UTF-16 and the now-obsolete UCS-2

qas.question: What does UTF-8 use in terms of bytes?

answers.text: UTF-8 uses one byte for any ASCII character

qas.question: What type of code does UCS-2 use?
What are character encodings implemented by?
Which two encodings are now obsolete?
How many ASCII characters are used to make one UTF-8?
What system has a minimum of four bytes?

context: <b5_0>Unicode<b5_0/> can be implemented by different character encodings. The most commonly used encodings are <a0_0><b6_0>UTF-8, UTF-16<b6_0/> and the now-obsolete UCS-2<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b9_0>UTF-8<b9_0/> uses <b8_0>one<b8_0/> byte for any ASCII character<a1_0/>, all of which have the same code values in both UTF-8 and ASCII encoding, and up to four bytes for other characters. UCS-2 uses a <a2_0>16-bit code unit<a2_0/> (two 8-bit bytes) for each character but cannot encode every character in the current Unicode standard. <b7_0>UTF-16<b7_0/> extends <a3_0>UCS-2<a3_0/>, using one 16-bit unit for the characters that were representable in UCS-2 and two 16-bit units <a4_0>(4 × 8 bits<a4_0/>) to handle each of the additional characters.
